Executive Summary:
Attached File Name: Mer.acs
6/08/04
                           Summary
           Royster-Clark Nitrogen - Meredosia, IL
                              
A.   Introduction:
The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Terminal in Meredosia receives
fertilizers from barges, stores the fertilizer in tanks, and
loads trucks. The facility has one anhydrous ammonia tank
and four urea ammonium nitrate (UAN) liquid fertilizer
storage tanks.

B.   Accidental Release Record:

The Royster-Clark Nitrogen, Meredosia Terminal, has an
excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries
to facility personnel since it was constructed in 1964.

The facility safety record is direct result of continued
emphasis on safety by management, employees, contractors,
and truck drivers. There have not been any releases from the
Terminal that meet the description of an RMP accidental
release.

In case of a reportable chemical accident, information in
the RMP will be updated within six (6) months of the date
accident accrued.

C.   General Accidental Release Prevention Policies And
  Activities:

Royster-Clark Nitrogen believes safety and concern for the
environment must be second nature to all employees and
contractor personnel.

The entire Royster-Clark Nitrogen team works together to
ensure the facility complies with OSHA'S Process Safety
Management standards and the accident prevention program are
continuously improved. A networked computer management
system is utilized to provide our employees with the
necessary tools and records to maintain the safety of the
process. This teamwork is an integral part in the safety
efforts of the facility.

Accident release prevention steps include the fourteen-
element program for Process Safety Management, a management
system, corporate oversight of the facility, and a focus on
continuous improvement.

Royster-Clark Nitrogen encourages all employees to
participate in the facility's safety program. Exa

mples of
employee participation include participation in Process
Hazard Analysis, cooperative training, updating of operating
procedures, and emergency response activities.

Royster-Clark Nitrogen has well established practices and
procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems,
relief and vent systems, controls, pump compressors, and
emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.
This program includes:
1.   training
2.   written operating procedures
3.   inspection and test in accordance with recognized
  standard,
4.   correction of deficiencies,
5.   quality assurance

In combination, these activities from a system that
maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of
the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) emergency
response plans, and (4) applicable safe work practices to
help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe
manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is
performed in a consistent manner, conforms to generally
accepted standards, and provides a basis for training.
Inspections and test are performed to help ensure that
equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment
is within acceptable limits.

Royster-Clark Nitrogen has a comprehensive system to manage
changes to processes. This system requires that changes to
items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology,
procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed
and authorized before being implemented.

D.   Worst Case Scenario:

This information was removed from the executive summary in
accordance with (40 CFR 68.190 (b) (6).

E.   Anhydrous Ammonia Alternative Scenario:

The conditions picked for the alternative case scenario are
those which would create a maximum amount of loss of
anhydrous ammonia from a vessel of ammonia. The scenario
involves breakage of the sight glass and failure of the
ammonia check valve res

ulting in loss of 100 gallons of hot
anhydrous ammonia to the atmosphere.

F.   Five Year Accident History:

The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Meredosia Terminal has an
excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries
to any of its personnel. In addition, the terminal has
operated without a lost time accident for over twenty-eight
years. There have not been any incidents that meet the
definition of a RMP recordable release.

G.   Emergency Response:

The facility Emergency Action Plans covers accidental
releases of plant chemicals, natural disasters, emergency
response practices and procedures, and process safety
topics. The plan is reviewed at least annually with all
employees.
All permanent employees have the required Hazmat training,
including an eight-hour refresher course annually. Each
employee and permanent contractor is trained on the
facility's Emergency Response policies and procedures at
regularly scheduled safety meetings.
The Terminal manager and his assistant attend monthly
Community Advisory Panel meetings. This panel includes other
area industries, Meredosia Village board members, local
emergency response agencies, community leaders and citizens.

The Emergency Response Plan is followed in the event of an
emergency. The emergency alarm system is tested once each
month and an emergency drill is held at least annually.

Updates to emergency contact information will be reported
within one month of change.

H.   Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Meredosia Terminal will utilize
employee input and industry best management practices to
continuously improve safety, environmental, and all
operations.

I.   Summary:

The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Meredosia Terminal and its
employees are extremely proud of its safety record and the
vast improvements in both safety and environmental. We
believe that with the programs and policies in place in our
terminal and the continued efforts of 10

0% of our personnel,
we will be able to maintain our safety record and a safe
plant environment for all concerned in the years ahead.
